evidence: Sheikh et al. developed a new ductile refractory BCC HEA, Hf 0.5 Nb 0.5 Ta 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr, with the objective to achieve the intrinsic ductility
BCC solid solutions retain yield stresses superior to 500 MPa up to 600 °C.
Under extreme temperatures (> 1200 °C) only MoNbTaW and MoN-bTaVW maintain incredible strengths (405 and 477 MPa at 1600 °C for MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW, respectively).
Under extreme temperatures (> 1200 °C) only MoNbTaW and MoN-bTaVW maintain incredible strengths (405 and 477 MPa at 1600 °C for MoNbTaW and MoNbTaVW, respectively).

The lowest yield stress value (540 MPa) is obtained for the TRIP HEA with Hf 1.4 Nb 0.25 Ta 0.25 Ti 1.75 Zr 1.4 composition. In this case a fully BCC recrystallized microstructure has been tested in uniaxial tension and the appearance of a stress-induced martensite enables to achieve a strong work-hardening rate of 3 GPa (0.103 if normalized by shear modulus) and an interesting tensile ductility as high as 23%.

The most attractive behavior at RT is obtained with the refractory MoNbTaVW composition prepared by MA and SPS with grains of nanometers size, while keeping a limited but reasonable plastic deformation of 8.8%.

The HfNbTaTiZr alloy is actually the sole equiatomic BCC solid solution whose microstructure (grain size) could be easily controlled by cold rolling and subsequent annealing. It also displays a good tensile ductility as high as 15% in well-recrystallized samples.
A true tensile stress of 1295 MPa and tensile ductility of 4.7% was reported for the sheet that was strained to 86.4% thickness reduction.

In dynamic conditions, i.e. for strain rates higher than 1 s -1 , intense slip activity and/or macroscopic band shearing are evidenced in the as solidified HfNbTaTiZr solid solution  [68] . At a strain rate of 4.53 s -1 , deformation is heterogeneous in the grains and localized in wavy bands for which lattice rotations are intense.

Few studies exist for the study of mechanical properties below the ambient for BCC HEAs, except that of Podolskiy et al. on the grade Hf 0.75 NbTa 0.5 Ti 1.5 Zr 1.25  [59] . This may be related to the difficulty of making such experiments.

Fig. 4. Illustration of the evolution of the macroscopic mechanical behavior of as-cast HfNbTaTiZr alloy as a function of the strain rate at RT. Compression tests at velocities above 10 m•s -1 were performed by direct impact loading [68] .
Fig. 7. An example of a fracture surface of HfNbTaTiZr (recrystallized microstructure) after four points bending fatigue test (σ max ′ = 965 MPa, N f = 1,621,220 cycles). A crack propagation zone (possibly transgranular) is identified on the top left (indicated by a white arrow). A final rupture zone is shown at the right bottom which shows shallow dimples as found in previous tensile tests on as-cast microstructure [69].
